thread.title: Nigerian mother owes NHS nearly £500,000 after giving birth on a plane | London - ITV News
thread.title_full: Nigerian mother owes NHS nearly £500,000 after giving birth on a plane | London - ITV News

title: Nigerian mother owes NHS nearly £500,000 after giving birth on a plane | London - ITV News
text:
1 February 2017 at 10:15am Nigerian mother owes NHS nearly £500,000 after giving birth on a plane 
A Nigerian mother who gave birth to quadruplets on a plane to the UK, two of whom died, now owes the NHS nearly £500,000. 
The woman, named as Priscilla, reportedly went into premature labour as she was flying home from America, via Heathrow. 
One of her babies did not survive the birth and the remaining three were taken to neonatal intensive care at St Mary's Hospital in west London. 
A second baby, named Deborah, died on Saturday, according to The Sun newspaper. 
While recovering in hospital, Priscilla was told she must pay the cost of her healthcare, estimated to be more than £20,000 a week and expected to reach £500,000. St Mary's Hospital, Paddington Credit: PA Emergency NHS treatment is free but non-UK residents have to be billed. The system for recovering cash from overseas patients was criticised in a recent report by MPs from the Commons Public Accounts Committee £289 million was charged to all overseas patients in 2015/16, with trusts collecting only around half of the amounts they invoice The Government has a target to recover up to #500 million a year by 2017/18 from all overseas patients, though it is widely expected to miss this Last updated Wed 1 Feb 2017
